resources.string: There is a difference in headings between native apps and hybrids with embedded HTML content. While there are six levels of headings in HTML h1 to h6. This is not the case with native apps. In native apps, the attribute android:accessibilityHeading \"tue\" is used to mark up a text (textView) on a non-visual level as a heading.

Contrast ratio is one of the aspects of accessibility that is often not given enough attention in the development of mobile apps. However, especially in mobile use, a good contrast ratio is important for all users, e.g., when using mobile devices outdoors in the sunshine. Below are a few examples of good and bad contrast ratios.

The following will show what is read by TalkBack in the 3 most common situations (no alternative text, decorative graphics, and informative graphics). To provide an alternative text to graphics the attribute android:contentDescription=\" \" is used.

In this example, the alternative text was intentionally omitted. In practice, it happens very often that the alternative text is omitted by mistake. For this example, the symbol for non-wheelchair accessible is used (a crossed-out wheelchair symbol).

In this example, the graphic was assumed to be purely decorative and the alternative text was left blank so that TalkBack ignores the graphic and does not output irrelevant text. The wheelchair symbol was used for this example.
In this example, the graphic was assumed to be informative, so it was provided with an alternative text.

In the following, we will show how TalkBack behaves when the visually visible labels have not been linked to the corresponding input field. In order to link the visually visible labels with the corresponding input fields, the attribute android:labelFor=\" \" is used for the label with the ID belonging to the editText as value.
In the first input field, the link to the visible label was intentionally omitted. The second was correctly linked to the label.
Press the button below to display your full name.
The current version of WCAG is 2.1.
The current version was released in june 2018.
What is the current version of WCAG?
When was the current version of WCAG released?

This example shows how TalkBack behaves in relation to graphical buttons with missing alternative text, and at the same time shows how the buttons can be made more usable for people with limited fine motor skills.

In the first graphic button, the alternative text, the attribute contentDescription=\" \" was intentionally omitted and the font target was also not adjusted. The second graphic button, however, was correctly labelled and the touch target was adjusted by setting the attributes minWidth and minHeight to 48dp so that the button is displayed larger and is thus easier to use.
Question #1: What is the current version of WCAG?
Question #2: When was the current version of WCAG released?
Get the answer to the second question.
